column1: TRUMP FANS VS. CLINTON SUPPORTERS

The Reuters/Ipsos poll asked people to grade whites and blacks on a series of personal traits. The results were then analyzed to compare how each respondent rated whites with how they rated blacks.In nearly every case
column2: Trump supporters were more likely to rate whites higher than blacks when their responses were compared with responses from Clinton supporters. For example
column3: 32 percent of Trump supporters placed whites closer to the top level of ""intelligence"" than they did blacks
column4: compared with 22 percent of Clinton supporters who did the same.About 40 percent of Trump supporters placed whites higher on the ""hardworking"" scale than blacks
column5: while 25 percent of Clinton supporters did the same. And 44 percent of Trump supporters placed whites as more ""well mannered"" than blacks
column6: compared with 30 percent of Clinton supporters.The online poll
column7: which surveyed people over the age of 18 across the United States
column8: was conducted during two periods in the 2016 election cycle.The first ran three weeks in March and April
column9: while Cruz and Kasich were still competing with Trump for the Republican nomination. The second polling period covered nearly four weeks in May and June
column10: after Kasich and Cruz had dropped out. (Editing by Paul Thomasch and Ross Colvin)"	['Sanders'

column1: By David Morgan
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Democratic U.S. presidential hopeful Bernie Sanders brought his firebrand rhetoric back to the floor of the Senate on Tuesday to condemn a White House-backed bill on Puerto Rico's financial crisis as ""colonialism at its worst.""Sanders
column2: a self-described democratic socialist who turned an unlikely presidential bid into a political movement to combat inequality

Sanders fumed during an eight-minute appearance to support an hours-long speech by Democratic Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey
column4: who opposes the bill.

column1: The Vermont senator used his appearance to rail against details of the legislation

column7: ""I know this sounds so absurd that people may think I'm misleading them.""

column1: 9	9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-congress-islam-idUSKCN0ZE2U4	Cruz chairs contentious U.S. Senate hearing on 'radical Islam'	"
By Julia Harte
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Republican U.S. Senator Ted Cruz on Tuesday accused the Obama administration of under-emphasizing the ""threat of radical Islam"" as he presided over a Senate hearing for the second time since suspending his presidential campaign in early May.President Barack Obama and top Justice Department officials have come under fire from conservatives for avoiding the term ""radical Islam"" when denouncing attacks by violent extremists who claim inspiration from Islamic State
column2: such as the Orlando nightclub shooter. Administration officials have countered that focusing on the use of the phrase is a political distraction and gives fuel to Islamic State propagandists who say the United States has waged war against all of Islam.Absent from Tuesday's hearing before a subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee were the two top Justice Department counter-terrorism officials whom Cruz had invited to testify.

column1: The Obama administration of course has declined to appear and explain its policies
column2: Cruz said at the hearing
column3: noting that the officials had not provided any reason for staying away.Justice Department spokesman Marc Raimondi said in an emailed statement that the department is ""focused on aggressively and successfully pursuing terrorist adversaries"" and on denying them ""unchallenged recruiting platforms to spread their messages of hate and intolerance.""

column1: Democratic members of the subcommittee said national security policies more targeted at Muslims
column2: such as presumptive Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump's call for a ban on Muslim immigrants
column3: would be unconstitutional and counter-productive.""We cannot fight radicalization with further radicalization
column4: said Democratic Senator Christopher Coons of Delaware
column5: adding at the end of the hearing that he did not think ""arguing over semantics"" for three hours had helped improve American national security.

column1: Experts from Muslim and Arab advocacy groups as well as former government national security officials testified at the hearing
column2: representing both sides of the debate over whether the administration emphasizes Islam too much or too little in its counter-extremism policies.Protesters with Code Pink
column3: an anti-war advocacy group
column4: offered Cruz packs of gum labeled ""Islamophobin"" as he entered the hearing room
column5: telling him it could cure Islamophobia.     (Reporting by Julia Harte; Editing by Cynthia Osterman)"	['Cruz'
